 The concept of Eugenics was perceived during the first part of the twentieth century as an oppurtunity for humans to control their own evolutionary destiny. Eugenics have been given a bad reputation by Adolf Hitler's pseudoscientifically-backed racism as well as the highly uninformed endeavor that took place in America in 1910 by Charles Davenport called the Eugenics Record Office at Cold Spring Harbor.
 
 True Eugenics is based upon the premise of promoting good genes, for example a chromosome 21 that lacks the gene that makes skin cancer 90% likely to be expressed in a human's phenotype at an early age. This would entail making a conscious choice not to mate if you had the gene, or choosing not to mate with a member of the opposite sex with someone who had an undesirable gene. Eugenics is simply humanity attempting through science to control evolution to remove detrimental genetic mutation. This, I think most agree, is a genuinely good endeavor.
 
 Please people, research things before trying to debate about them.
Clive14

Even "True Eugenics" is a seriously flawed concept, both morally and biologically.
 
 Dealing with the latter first, how do you determine "good genes". There is no simple one to one mapping of gene and function: genes have multiple functions and functions are driven by multiple genes. All we could ever do (until our knowledge of the interactions of the genone, protosome, "junk" DNA functionality and RNA roles dramatically increase) is tinker at the edges, not being completely sure of the full affects of our tinkerings.
 
 And even if we could work out detailed gene functionality, who morally decides a good gene versus a bad one? Taking your example of the gene on chromosome 21. What if I have it, but choose to have kids anyway? Would society seek to stop me? Would it put emotional pressure upon me not to? Financial pressure? Discrimination of some sort? Of course it would: it is inevitable it would, for that is human nature. The forced sterilization of immigrants into the USA in the 1920s and Hilter's actions are inevitable consequences of encouraging societies to adopt the ideas of eugenics. It is an appalling idea and people need to be reminded that Hilter adopted it every time it is in danger of becoming popular, for it is an idea that belongs firmly in our past.
